title: Apps like UrbanClap, YepMe, Koovs get a design makeover this festive season
text: #customers experience Apps like UrbanClap, YepMe, Koovs get a design makeover this festive season Just as the festivities were setting in, UrbanClap, like several other players, decided to launch packages and offers. “We placed a new section of Diwali offers on top of the app and that is drawing in a lot of users,“ said Varun Khaitan, cofounder, UrbanClap. | ET Bureau | 24 October 2015, 5:05 PM IST Follow ETCIO Share CHENNAI: In the quest for providing customers with a seamless experience, startups have begun including user experience (UX) design in their checklist and are increasingly seeking specialised designers to groom their mobile applications.Just as the festivities were setting in, UrbanClap, like several other players, decided to launch packages and offers. "We placed a new section of Diwali offers on top of the app and that is drawing in a lot of users," said Varun Khaitan, cofounder, UrbanClap."We are also doing things like ondemand Mehandi activity for Karva Chauth and for that we are making some changes on our app."User experience design is the process of making the webapp interface more user-friendly, interactive, pleasing and accessible.While Khaitan would like to broadly term it "product-changes for which design changes are significant", several others who are doling out app-only offers are taking the design of their apps seriously.Nishant Jain, partner (UX) of Design For Use, said: "I must have talked to at least six-seven fashion apps and this is over the last two months, clearly for the NovemberDecember sales. They are not just thinking about backend works and inventory anymore, but also realise the importance of design."Jain believes that design's role is in solving the user's problem and in inspiring the customer to buy something not thought about before. He observes that the demand is mostly coming from smaller companies. "The big players have a very data-centric approach, which means that they are making design decisions based on data. Smaller ones are taking design more seri ously during this festive season, because they need to position themselves unique among the others," said Jain.Nevertheless, he has also been approached by the likes of YepMe, Koovs and Nykaa to spruce up their looks for the season. While Jain quips that he is finding it almost impossible to find designers this festive season, Aashish Solanki, founder and CEO of NetBramha, estimates a three-fold increase in traffic and engagement. "There is scope for adding a lot of specific features in the app-design during festive seasons," Solanki said."Scheduling the delivery is going to be interesting. Delivery and gifting on the day of the festival and those sort of personalisations via the app are being included in the design aspects." According to Solanki, returns is going to be a challenging area where design and analytics would need to work hand-in-hand. "Tonnes of brainstorming is happening with designers giving about 100-200 ideas and accordingly they (online companies) have to work with their back-end and logistics," he said.
